rev.diff:
Line 59: Line 59:
==''We are all Khaled Said''==
==''We are all Khaled Said''==
[[File:Khaled Saeed by Kimo Nour.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A poster of "Khaled Mohamed Saeed"]]
[[File:Khaled Saeed by Kimo Nour.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A poster of "Khaled Mohamed Saeed"]]
â
Among those who saw the photo, was Google marketing executive [[Wael Ghonim]]. Ghonim was located in [[Dubai]] at the time of the incident and decided to create a [[Facebook]] memorial page for Saeed, called "We are all Khaled Said". The page attracted hundreds of thousands of followers, becoming Egypt's biggest dissident Facebook page.<ref name="NYTFB">{{Cite news |title=Facebook and YouTube Fuel the Egyptian Protests |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/06/world/middleeast/06face.html |date=February 5, 2011 |last=Preston |first=Jennifer |work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name="NATO">{{cite web | url = http://www.nato.int/docu/review/2011/Social_Medias/Egypt_Facebook/EN/index.htm | title = Egypt and Facebook: Time to Update Its Status | work = Nato Review | publisher = [[NATO]] | year = 2011 | accessdate = 19 March 2011 | last = Heaven | first = Will}}</ref> Support for Saeed rapidly spread,<ref name=ABC/><ref name=NATO/> with many Facebook members using his photograph for their own profiles.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/africa/undercover-police-arrested-over-beating-death-of-egyptian-man | title = Undercover Police Arrested Over Beating Death of Egyptian Man | author = Nadia abou el Magd | date = 2 July 2010 | accessdate = 19 March 2011 | work = [[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]}}</ref>
+
Among those who saw the photo, was Google marketing executive [[Wael Ghonim]]. Ghonim was located in [[Dubai]] at the time of the incident and decided to create a [[Facebook]] memorial page for Saeed, called "We are all Khaled Said". The page attracted hundreds of thousands of followers, becoming Egypt's biggest dissident Facebook page.<ref name="NYTFB">{{Cite news |title=Facebook and YouTube Fuel the Egyptian Protests |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/06/world/middleeast/06face.html |date=February 5, 2011 |last=Preston |first=Jennifer |work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name="NATO">{{cite web | url = http://www.nato.int/docu/review/2011/Social_Medias/Egypt_Facebook/EN/index.htm | title = Egypt and Facebook: Time to Update Its Status | work = Nato Review | publisher = [[NATO]] | year = 2011 | accessdate = 19 March 2011 | last = Heaven | first = Will}}</ref> Support for Saeed rapidly spread,<ref name=ABC/><ref name=NATO/> with many Facebook members using his photograph for their own profiles.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/africa/undercover-police-arrested-over-beating-death-of-egyptian-man | title = Undercover Police Arrested Over Beating Death of Egyptian Man | author = Nadia abou el Magd | date = 2 July 2010 | accessdate = 19 March 2011 | work = [[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]}}</ref> Run by an obsessively anonymous administrator, it started with posts about Saidâs case. But the page quickly spiraled into an all-out campaign against police brutality and rights abuses in Egyptâbecoming a clearinghouse for information, posting often-graphic photo and video, and publishing the names of allegedly abusive cops.<ref>{{cite web|title="We Are All Khaled Said": Will the Revolution Come to Egypt?|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/01/22/we-are-all-khaled-said-will-the-revolution-come-to-egypt.html|publisher=http://www.thedailybeast.com/|accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> The page is credited for turning police brutality into a popular debate. The group has organized demonstrations in honor of Said on January 25, national police day, and on January 22, 2011 its membership is approaching 380,000, which made it the countryâs largest and most active online human-rights activist group.<ref>{{cite web|title="We Are All Khaled Said": Will the Revolution Come to Egypt?|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/01/22/we-are-all-khaled-said-will-the-revolution-come-to-egypt.html|publisher=http://www.thedailybeast.com/|accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>. As of Januray 21 nearly 69,000 people had signed on to the Jan. 25 protest on the âWe Are All Khaled Saidâ Facebook page.<ref>{{cite web|title="We Are All Khaled Said": Will the Revolution Come to Egypt?|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/01/22/we-are-all-khaled-said-will-the-revolution-come-to-egypt.html|publisher=http://www.thedailybeast.com/|accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
  +
==Investigation and trial of the police officers==
Because of the photo and the heavy amount of international criticism that arose from the incident, the Egyptian government consented to a trial for the two detectives involved in his death.<ref>{{cite news |title=We are all Khaled Saeed: Redefining political demonstration in Egypt |author=Noha El-Hennawy |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/61266 |newspaper=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=August 4, 2010 |accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref>
Because of the photo and the heavy amount of international criticism that arose from the incident, the Egyptian government consented to a trial for the two detectives involved in his death.<ref>{{cite news |title=We are all Khaled Saeed: Redefining political demonstration in Egypt |author=Noha El-Hennawy |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/61266 |newspaper=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=August 4, 2010 |accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref>
â
==Investigation and trial of the police officers==
+
The investigation into Saeed's death yielded 300 papers, analysis and testimony which informed the decision to charge both police officers, Mahmoud Salah Mahmoud and Awad Ismael Suleiman, in criminal court with use of violence and unjustified detention of the victim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/55686 |title=exclusive: Khaled Saeed case investigation | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> They were detained in July 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/53178 |title=2 Alex policemen detained in Khaled Saeed case | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2010-06-30 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> and the trial began in July but was postponed and did not resume until February 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/302734 |title=Alexandriaâs Khaled Saeed police brutality trial postponed | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-01-22 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The Alexandria Criminal Court will announce the verdict on September 24.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0630/Khaled-Said-verdict-and-Egyptian-justice-delayed-again |title=Khaled Said verdict â and Egyptian justice â delayed again |publisher=''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' |date=2011-06-30 |accessdate=2011-07-1}}</ref>
The investigation into Saeed's death yielded 300 papers, analysis and testimony which informed the decision to charge both police officers, Mahmoud Salah Mahmoud and Awad Ismael Suleiman, in criminal court with use of violence and unjustified detention of the victim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/55686 |title=exclusive: Khaled Saeed case investigation | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> They were detained in July 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/53178 |title=2 Alex policemen detained in Khaled Saeed case | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2010-06-30 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> and the trial began in July but was postponed and did not resume until February 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/302734 |title=Alexandriaâs Khaled Saeed police brutality trial postponed | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-01-22 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The Alexandria Criminal Court will announce the verdict on September 24.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0630/Khaled-Said-verdict-and-Egyptian-justice-delayed-again |title=Khaled Said verdict â and Egyptian justice â delayed again |publisher=''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' |date=2011-06-30 |accessdate=2011-07-1}}</ref>
